revision.text:
{{Infobox book | name = The Black Book of Poland
The German New Order in Poland | image = The Black Book of Poland (21–24).jpg | image_size = 260px | alt = | caption = Plates 21–24 inserted between pages 74 and 75 of ''The Black Book'', illustrating ''Part I. Massacres and Tortures''
{{unbulleted list|21–22: Hangings of civilians |23. Page from [[Special Prosecution Book-Poland]] |24. Aftermath of a massacre}} | author = Authority of the Polish Ministry of Information | publisher = Ministry of Information of the [[Polish government-in-exile]] | pub_date = 1942 | published = G.P. Putnam's Sons, New York
London edition has title: ''The German New Order in Poland.'' Published by Hutchinson & Co., London, UK | media_type = [[Hardcover]] | pages = 750 | oclc = 489805 }} '''''The Black Book of Poland''''' is a 750-page report published in 1942 by the Ministry of Information of the [[Polish government-in-exile]], describing atrocities committed by Germany in [[occupied Poland]] in twenty-two months between the [[invasion of Poland]] in September 1939, and the end of June 1941.{{cite book |title=The Black Book of Poland |url=https://archive.org/details/TheBlackBookOfPoland |location=New York |publisher=G.P. Putnam's Sons |year=1942 |OCLC=489805 |author=Authority of the Polish Ministry of Information}} All estimates, presented in the book section by section, are based on data collected while [[Operation Barbarossa|the war in the East]] was in progress, and the killing of Jews by means of carbon monoxide gas during [[Operation Reinhard]] – launched in 1942 for the implementation of the "[[Final Solution]]" – only began.{{cite news |title=200,000 Jews Executed by Nazis in Poland, Black Book Asserts |location=NEW YORK |date=September 8, 1942 |url=https://www.jta.org/1942/09/08/archive/200000-jews-executed-by-nazis-in-poland-black-book-asserts |author=Jewish Telegraphic Agency |id=[http://pdfs.jta.org/1942/1942-09-08_208.pdf Original publication: JTA NEWS. 9/8/42, p. 4. PDF direct download.]}} All casualties are partially summarized. The book includes documentation proving more than 400,000 cases of deliberate killings at an average of 1,576 per day. It is also considered a follow-up to ''[[The Polish White Book]]'' of 1941. ==Contents== ''The Black Book'' is a collection of authenticated documents, depositions, eye-witness accounts, and Ministerial summaries, describing and illustrating with photographs, the [[Nazi crimes against the Polish nation]] and [[War crimes in occupied Poland during World War II]] committed in mere two years: including massacres, tortures, expulsions, forced colonization, persecution, destruction of culture, and humiliation of a nation. The book is a sequel to ''The German Invasion of Poland'' compiled by the Polish government-in-exile and published in 1940, sometimes considered as the first volume of this publication series. The original volume deals with the war crimes of the September 1939 invasion of Poland. ''The Black Book'' by [[G.P. Putnam's Sons]] of New York (or the 'second volume' of ''The Black Book of Poland'') was published in London by [[Hutchinson (publisher)|Hutchinson]] under a different title: '''''The German New Order in Poland''''', with only 585 pages and 61 plates.{{cite book |author=National Library of Australia |url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/version/26862125 |title=The German new order in Poland |at=Illustrated edition: xiv, 585 pp. London, 1942 (1943). Published for the Polish Ministry of Information by Hutchinson & Co. |OCLC=58940954}}
{{cite book |author=OCLC WorldCat |title=The German new order in Poland |publisher=Ministerstwo Informacji. Poland |id=Hutchinson and Co., Ltd. [1943], London |url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/german-new-order-in-poland/oclc/58940954}} ''The Black Book'' is composed of nine sections, preceded by an Introduction titled 'Hora Tenebrarum'. All sections include long Appendices. ===Book sections=== # ''Part I. Massacres and Tortures'' # ''Part II. The Expulsion of the Polish Population from its Land'' # ''Part III. The Persecution of the Jews, and the Ghettos'' # ''Part IV. The Robbery of Public and Private Property'' # ''Part V. The Economic Exploitation of Polish Territories under German Occupation'' # ''Part VI. Religious Persecution'' # ''Part VII. Humiliation and Degradation of the Polish Nation'' # ''Part VIII. The Destruction of Polish Culture'' # ''Part IX. Violations by the Reich of International Law''. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} == External links == *Worldcat.org, [http://www.worldcat.org/title/black-book-of-poland/oclc/489805?referer=di&ht=edition 'The Black Book of Poland / The German New Order in Poland'.] *[http://m.neon24.pl/bd951a0a2f092fc7b46420a0db74e32d,0,0.jpg Photograph of the book with dust jacket.] ''The German New Order in Poland''. [https://archive.is/7GFjc Reprint. Archive.is] [[Category:Government reports]] [[Category:1942 in Poland]] [[Category:1942 documents]] [[Category:1942 in England]] [[Category:Holocaust historiography]] [[Category:Holocaust historical documents]] [[Category:The Holocaust in Poland]] [[Category:International response during the Holocaust]]

{{Infobox Organization |name = The Institute for Cultural Research |image = The_Institute_for_Cultural_Research_Logo.jpg |image_border = |size = 88px |caption = <small>Official logo</small> |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = |motto = |formation = 1965 |extinction = 2013 |type = NGO, educational charity, publisher |status = |purpose = Thought, behaviour and culture |headquarters = London, UK |location = |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = Director of Studies |leader_name = Originally [[Idries Shah]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = [http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/ Official website] |remarks = }}
'''The Institute for Cultural Research''' (ICR) was a [[London]]-based, [[United Kingdom|UK]]-registered educational [[Charitable organization|charity]],<ref name="reg-char">The Institute for Cultural Research's UK registered [[Charitable organization|charity]] number is 313295.</ref><ref name="charity">[http://www.guidestar.org.uk/gs_summary.aspx?CCReg=313295 Details of charitable status and activities at GuideStar.org.uk] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref><ref name="charity-commission">[http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/SHOWCHARITY/RegisterOfCharities/CharityWithoutPartB.aspx?RegisteredCharityNumber=313295&SubsidiaryNumber=0 313295 - THE INSTITUTE FOR CULTURAL RESEARCH - Official details of charitable status and activities at the Charity Commission] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> events organizer and [[Publishing|publisher]] which aimed to stimulate study, [[debate]], [[education]] and [[research]] into all aspects of human thought, [[Human behavior|behaviour]] and [[culture]].<ref name="ICR-Ceased-2014">{{cite web | author = Staff | first = | title = The Institute for Cultural Research | publisher = The Institute for Cultural Research | date = 2014 | url = http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20140830031217/http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/ | archive-date = 30 August 2014 | accessdate = 2014-10-10}}</ref> It brought together many distinguished speakers, writers and Fellows over the years.
A statement issued in 2013 by the institute on its official web site read: "As of summer 2013, the Institute has suspended its activities following the formation of a new charity, [[The Idries Shah Foundation]]."<ref name="ICR-Ceased-2014" />
==History== The institute was founded in 1965 by the well-known writer, thinker and [[Sufism|Sufi]] teacher [[Idries Shah]]<ref name="wintle">Justin Wintle (ed), ''Makers of Modern Culture'', Volume I, p474, Routledge, 2001, {{ISBN|0-415-26583-5}}. Retrieved from Google book search [https://books.google.com/books?id=991tT3wSot0C&pg=PA474&dq=Idries+Shah+%22Institute+for+Cultural+Research%22&client=firefox-a here] on 2008-11-14.</ref><ref name="shah">[https://www.amazon.com/dp/product-description/0385079664 Biographical detail about Idries Shah at Amazon] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref><ref name="lessing">[http://ishk.net/sufis//lessing.html Doris Lessing's tribute to Idries Shah in ''The Times'', May 5, 1994] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> to facilitate the dissemination of ideas, information and understanding between cultures.<ref name="charity" /><ref name="icr-about">[http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/about.php About the Institute for Cultural Research] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> Its Objects and Regulations were officially first adopted on 21 January 1966.<ref name="guidestar-organisation">[http://www.guidestar.org.uk/gs_organ.aspx?CCReg=0AWV1MgzSc0%2fkY4xcMOB1g%3d%3d&strQuery= Details of the ICR's organisation at GuideStar.org.uk] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref>
In his book ''Listening to Idries Shah'', author, [[Psychotherapy|psychotherapist]] and tutor, [[Ivan Tyrrell]] recounts a conversation in which Shah explained his reasons for founding the ICR: "I want to attract ordinary people and help them think about psychological and cultural issues. But, as an individual, I can't easily get people to listen seriously. I discovered, however, that if I call myself an 'institute' – they will," Shah told him.<ref name="Tyrrell">{{cite book | last = Tyrrell | first = Ivan | authorlink = Ivan Tyrrell | title = Listening to Idries Shah: How Understanding Can Grow | publisher = Human Givens Publishing Ltd | date = 9 June 2016 | page = 89 | isbn = 1899398082}}</ref> Tyrrell adds: "I heard [Shah] say many times over the years, 'We live in an appearance culture' [...] That is one reason why it was necessary for him to create ICR: people like to join an organisation and be part of a community."<ref name="Tyrrell" />
Based for some time at [[Royal Tunbridge Wells|Tunbridge Wells]] in [[Kent]], the institute was later based in [[London]].<ref name=WOL>{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The World of Learning 1978–79 | publisher = Europa Publications | date = | location = | page = 1367 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MOUvAAAAMAAJ&q=Idries+Shah+%22Institute+for+Cultural+REsearch%22&dq=Idries+Shah+%22Institute+for+Cultural+REsearch%22&client=firefox-a&pgis=1 | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-905118-25-1}} Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> Shah acted as the Institute's Director of Studies whilst still alive.<ref name=WOL /><ref name="director">[http://www.idriesshah.com/ Obituary at official Idries Shah web site] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref><ref name="DTOB">{{cite web| last =Staff| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Idries Shah – Grand Sheikh of the Sufis whose inspirational books enlightened the West about the moderate face of Islam (obituary)| work =[[The Daily Telegraph]]| publisher =| date =| url =https://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=/et/96/12/7/ebshah07.html| doi =| accessdate =2008-10-16| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20000525070609/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/et?ac=001301712421770&rtmo=qMuJX999&atmo=99999999&pg=%2Fet%2F96%2F12%2F7%2Febshah07.html| archivedate =2000-05-25| deadurl =yes| df =}}</ref><ref name="ishk">[http://www.ishkbooks.com/ishk_history_east_west_9.html Biographical detail on Idries Shah] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120210716/http://www.ishkbooks.com/ishk_history_east_west_9.html |date=2008-11-20 }} at the [[Institute for the Study of Human Knowledge]] (USA) where he co-led a seminar with [[Robert E. Ornstein]] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize]]-winning novelist [[Doris Lessing]], who was influenced by Idries Shah,<ref name="Galin">Müge Galin, ''Between East and West: Sufism in the Novels of Doris Lessing'', State University of New York Press, 1997, Albany, NY, {{ISBN|0-312-10293-3}}.</ref> has also contributed to the Institute.<ref name="icr-mono" /><ref name="lessing-seminar">[http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/events/seminar/Jan1998/lessing1998.php Doris Lessing at the 1998 ICR seminar.], speaking on problems, myths and stories. Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref>
==Aims and remit== The Institute's stated aim was "to stimulate study, debate, education and research into all aspects of human thought, behaviour and culture" and to make the results of its members' academic work accessible to society and also to academics working in different fields.<ref name="charity" /><ref name="icr-about" />
The body, which had a number of distinguished Fellows, published several dozen academic monographs and some books over the years<ref name="charity" /><ref name="icr-about" /> and held regular events.<ref name="charity" /><ref name="guidestar-statement">[http://www.guidestar.org.uk/gs_activities.aspx?CCReg=0AWV1MgzSc0%2fkY4xcMOB1g%3d%3d&strQuery= ICR's statement of public benefit at Guidestar.org.uk], made in light of the new Charities Act. Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> These events usually included a series of six lectures by specialists per year, and a two-day seminar which is usually held in the Autumn. The aim of these was "to connect ideas across disciplines, across cultures, and even through history" and to bring about a broader, more holistic understanding by looking at issues from several different perspectives, with particular interest in human thought and behaviour and issues neglected by contemporary culture.<ref name="guidestar-statement" /><ref name="icr-events">[http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/events/index.php Events held by the Institute for Cultural Research] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref>
In addition, the Institute supported projects in areas where freedom of access to facts was threatened,<ref name="charity" /> for example in the case of [[Afghanistan]] where assistance had been given to the [[United Nations Children's Fund]] (UNICEF)'s female educational projects.<ref name="icr-about" />
All the Institute for Cultural Research's activities were open to the general public.<ref name="charity" />
==Notable contributors== The institute published so many [[monograph]]s and hosted so many [[lecture]]s and [[seminar]]s that only a small sample of notable contributors are listed here.<ref name="scholar-list">[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?num=100&hl=en&lr=&safe=off&client=firefox-a&q=%22icr.org.uk%22&btnG=Search Google Scholar search results for ICR publications (pdf files)] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref>
See also [[:Category:People associated with The Institute for Cultural Research|People associated with The Institute for Cultural Research (category)]].
Lecturers included: * [[ecologist]], adventurer and writer [[John P. Allen]] (''Cultures and Biomes of the Biosphere'') * [[Psychology|psychologist]] [[Michael Eysenck]] (''Lost in Time, Making Sense of Amnesia'') * [[Neuroscience|neuroscientist]] Professor [[Chris Frith]] (how the brain creates our mental and social worlds) * British social [[Anthropology|anthropologist]] Professor [[Tim Ingold]] (the mismatch between the "environment" of immediate experience and the "Environment" of scientific and policy discourse) * writer and documentary [[Filmmaking|filmmaker]] [[Tahir Shah]] (the scientific legacies of the Arab Caliphates and their Golden Age) * writer and filmmaker [[Iain Sinclair]] (''Hackney, That Rose-Red Empire'') * poet, writer and adventurer [[Robert Twigger]] (''Polymaths in a monopathic world?'') * anthropologist [[Piers Vitebsky]] (''Global religious change and the death of the shaman'') * novelist, short story writer, [[historian]] and [[Mythography|mythographer]] [[Marina Warner]] (''Talismans and Charms: Spellbinding in Stories from The 1001 Nights'') * writer [[Ramsay Wood]] (''The Kalila and Dimna Story'')
Monograph writers included: * [[science writer]] [[Philip Ball]] (''Collective Behaviour and the Physics of Society''<ref name="ball-collective">Philip Ball, ''Collective Behaviour and the Physics of Society'', ICR Monograph Series No. 52, Institute for Cultural Research, 2007, {{ISBN|978-0-904674-44-6}}.</ref>) * [[diplomat]] and writer [[Robert Cecil (British diplomat)|Robert Cecil]] (''Cults in 19th Century Britain'',<ref name="Cults monograph">{{cite web | author = Cecil | first = Robert | title = Cults in 19th Century Britain | work = | publisher = [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] | date = | url = https://idriesshahfoundation.org/cults-in-19th-century-britain/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181013151510/https://idriesshahfoundation.org/cults-in-19th-century-britain/ | archive-date = 13 Oct 2018 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 13 Oct 2018}}</ref> ''Cultural Imperialism'',<ref name="Imperialism monograph">{{cite web | author = Cecil | first = Robert | title = Cultural Imperialism | work = | publisher = [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] | date = | url = https://idriesshahfoundation.org/cultural-imperialism/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181013151602/https://idriesshahfoundation.org/cultural-imperialism/ | archive-date = 13 Oct 2018 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 13 Oct 2018}}</ref> and ''Education and Elitism in Nazi Germany''<ref name="Elitism monograph">{{cite web | author = Cecil | first = Robert | title = Education and Elitism in Nazi Germany | work = | publisher = [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] | date = | url = https://idriesshahfoundation.org/education-and-elitism-in-nazi-germany/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20181013151656/https://idriesshahfoundation.org/education-and-elitism-in-nazi-germany/ | archive-date = 13 Oct 2018 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 13 Oct 2018}}</ref>) * professor of [[psychiatry]] [[Arthur J. Deikman]] (''Evaluating Spiritual and Utopian Groups''<ref name="deikman">Arthur J. Deikman, M.D., ''Evaluating Spiritual and Utopian Groups'', Institute for Cultural Research, 1988, {{ISSN|0306-1906}}, {{ISBN|0-904674-13-4}}.</ref>)<ref name="icr-mono">[http://www.i-c-r.org.uk/publications/monographarchive.php List of Institute for Cultural Research monographs] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> * psychologist and noted [[Skepticism|skeptic]] [[Chris French]] (''Paranormal Perception? A Critical Evaluation''<ref name="french">Christopher C. French, ''Paranormal Perception? A Critical Evaluation'', Institute for Cultural Research, 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-904674-34-7}}.</ref>) * co-founder of the [[Club of Rome]] in 1968, [[Alexander King (scientist)|Dr. Alexander King]] (''Science, Technology and the Quality of Life''<ref name="king-science">Alexander King, ''Science, Technology and the Quality of Life'', The Institute for Cultural Research, 1972, {{ISSN|0306-1906}}, {{ISBN|0-9500029-8-4}}.</ref> and ''An Eye to the Future''<ref name="alex-eye">Dr. Alexander King et al., ''An Eye to the Future'', Institute for Cultural Research, {{ISBN|978-0-9500029-1-0}}.</ref>)<ref name="king">[http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=Alexander_King SourceWatch article on Alexander King] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> * [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize]]-winning novelist [[Doris Lessing]] (''Problems, Myths and Stories''<ref name="lessing-problems">Doris Lessing, ''Problems, myths and stories'', The Institute for Cultural Research, 1999, {{ISSN|0306-1906}}, {{ISBN|0-904674-28-2}}.</ref>) * professor of telecommunications [[Leonard Lewin (telecommunications engineer)|Leonard Lewin]] (''Science and the Paranormal''<ref name="lewin-paranormal">Leonard Lewin, ''Science and the Paranormal'', The Institute for Cultural Research, 1999, {{ISSN|0306-1906}}, {{ISBN|0-904674-07-X}}.</ref>) * professor of [[archaeology]] [[Steven Mithen]] (''Problem-solving and the Evolution of Human Culture''<ref name="mithen-problem">Steven Mithen, Monograph Series No. 33, ''Problem-solving and the Evolution of Human Culture'', The Institute for Cultural Research, 1999, {{ISSN|0306-1906}}, {{ISBN|0-904674-25-8}}.</ref>) * writer and psychologist [[Robert E. Ornstein]] (''Physiological Studies of Consciousness''<ref name="ornstein-evan">Robert E. Ornstein and Robert Evan, ''Physiological studies of consciousness'', ICR Monograph Series No. 11, Institute for Cultural Research, 1973, {{ISBN|0-904674-00-2}}.</ref>) * [[Biochemistry|biochemist]], [[Plant physiology|plant physiologist]] and [[Parapsychology|parapsychologist]] [[Rupert Sheldrake]] (''Fields of the Mind''<ref name="sheldrake-fields">Rupert Sheldrake, ''Fields of the Mind'', ICR Monograph Series No. 55, Institute for Cultural Research, 2009, {{ISBN|978-0-904674-47-7}}.</ref>)
Books published by the ICR included ''[[Cultural Research]]''<ref name="cult-research">Tahir Shah (ed), ''Cultural Research: Papers on Regional Cultures and Culture-Mixing, by and for the Institute for Cultural Research'', Institute for Cultural Research, 1993, {{ISBN|978-0-86304-064-1}}.</ref><ref name="tahir-cr">[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0863040640 Tahir Shah's ''Cultural Research'' at Amazon] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> edited by the writer [[Tahir Shah]], and ''Cultural Encounters: Essays on the interactions of diverse cultures now and in the past'',<ref name="cult-encounters">Robert Cecil and David Wade (eds), ''Cultural Encounters: Essays on the interactions of diverse cultures now and in the past'', Institute for Cultural Research, 1990, {{ISBN|978-0-86304-050-4}}.</ref><ref name="cecil-amazon">[https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/0863040500 ''Cultural Encounters'' at Amazon] Retrieved on 2008-11-14.</ref> edited by [[Robert Cecil (British diplomat)|Robert Cecil]] and David Wade.
